message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including involuntary lip smacking and hand and leg movements, suggest tardive dyskinesia, which is a side effect of long-term use of antipsychotic medications such as fluphenazine. Risperidone is also an antipsychotic medication, but it has weaker dopamine antagonism, which may explain the patient’s improvement. Weaker acetylcholine antagonism or agonism and weaker histamine agonism do not explain the patient’s improvement in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with tardive dyskinesia, a side effect of long-term antipsychotic treatment. Fluphenazine is a dopamine antagonist, and switching to risperidone, which has weaker dopamine antagonism, can improve symptoms. None of the other listed options are relevant to the mechanism of action of these medications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fluphenazine is a typical antipsychotic that acts by blocking dopamine receptors, which can cause side effects such as involuntary movements. Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that also blocks dopamine receptors but has a weaker antagonistic effect, which may explain why the patient's symptoms improved. There is no evidence to suggest that acetylcholine or histamine are involved in this case.

Risperidone also works on dopamine receptors but has a weaker antagonistic effect, which can help improve the patient’s symptoms. Acetylcholine and histamine are not as relevant to this case.
